body_content.explanation: the particular combination of qualities in a person or place that makes them different from others:
examples: Politeness is traditionally part of the British character.
It would be very out of character (= not typical) of her to lie.
One of the joys of being a parent is watching the child's character develop.
The idea was to modernize various aspects of the house without changing its essential character.
It's not in his character to be (= he is not usually) jealous.

body_content.explanation: qualities that are interesting and unusual:
examples: I'd prefer an old place with a bit of character.
Old books are said to give a room character.
As people grow older, their faces acquire more character.

body_content.explanation: the quality of being determined and able to deal with difficult situations:
examples: She has such strength of character.

body_content.explanation: a person represented in a film, play, or story:
examples: The film revolves around three main characters.
She had Mickey Mouse or some other cartoon/Disney character on her sweater.
He made his name as a character actor (= an actor who plays unusual and often humorous people).

body_content.explanation: a person, especially when you are describing a particular quality that they have:
examples: She's a curious character - I don't really know what to think of her.
There were one or two strange-looking characters hanging around the bar.

body_content.explanation: someone whose behaviour is different from most people's, especially in a way that is interesting or funny:
examples: Ted's quite a character/a real character - he's 70 now and still riding that motorbike.

body_content.explanation: a letter, number, or other mark or sign used in writing or printing, or the space one of these takes:
examples: a string of characters (= a line of marks)
The address was written in Chinese/Japanese characters (= systems of writing).
The computer screen on this laptop is 66 characters (= spaces) wide.
